Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WR3-84B1-DY0W-447M-00000-00Twitter And Facebook Executives Testify Before Congress; Protests Disrupt Second Day Of Kavanaugh Confirmation Hearings; 'New York Times' Runs Anonymous Op-Ed from Trump Administration Official; Radical Dems Pepper Kavanaugh with Outlandish Questions2018-09-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:58ZLexisNexisTwitter And Facebook Executives Testify Before Congress; Protests Disrupt Second Day Of Kavanaugh Confirmation Hearings; 'New York Times' Runs Anonymous Op-Ed from Trump Administration Official; Radical Dems Pepper Kavanaugh with Outlandish QuestionsLanhamFULL TEXT

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Let's see if they do. By the way, Vince, congratulations again. Great job. Here's Lou.

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. Our top stories, day two of the Kavanaugh Supreme Court confirmation hearings, the radical Dems still trying to disrupt and delay those hearings in spite of the outrageous ignorant conduct of the committee Dems and leftist protestors, President Trump's high court nominee handling their ignorance with grace and constraint.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I've watched his remarks, I've watched his performance, I've watched his statements and honestly they've been totally brilliant. I think that the other side is grasping at straws and really the other side should embrace it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Embrace it. We'll take up the latest on those hearings tonight, Congressman Andy Biggs among our guest. Also Fox Legal Analyst, Gregg Jarrett. Also, social media executives embarrassingly unprepared on Capitol Hill exposing themselves as unable, unwilling to address election meddling issues and acknowledge their political bias.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PATRICK DORSEY, FOUNDER AND CEO, TWITTER: We found ourselves unprepared and ill-equipped for the immensity of the problems that we've acknowledged.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: As for Google, didn't even show up, leaving lawmakers staring at empty an chair and perhaps -- just perhaps dreaming of ways to bring Google to heel. We take that up tonight with conservative social media starts, Diamond and Silk. And "The New York Times" taking fake news to the next level from anonymous sources to entire anonymous op-eds with anonymous quotes thrown in.

The President isn't too impressed by either "The Times" or the gutless wonder anonymous op-ed author.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: If the failing "New York Times" has an anonymous editorial, can you believe it? Anonymous, meaning gutless, a gutless editorial, we're doing a great job, the poll numbers are through the roof, our poll numbers are great and guess what, nobody is going to come close to beating me in 2020.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: We'll have more on the cowardly self-proclaimed senior official little worm who chose to betray and to attack the President that is if you believe the Times' claim about any of this. Our top story, the confirmation hearing for Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh still underway despite Dems spewing ignorance and vitriol all over the hearing room above it all Kavanaugh who makes his little effusion inquisitors from the left look ever smaller.

Fox News Chief Legal Correspondent and Anchor of "FOX NEWS @ NIGHT" Shannon Bream joining us from Capitol Hill with the latest.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

TRUMP: I've watched his performance, I've watched his statements and honestly they've been totally brilliant.

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS HOST: President Trump praising his second Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh as the judge continues to run a gauntlet marked by protestors. And Senators still jousting over document production.

SEN. PATRICK LEAHY (D), VERMONT: I would ask the chairman if he might look at some of these remarked committee confidential.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Let me answer that for you, if you're interested in it, you could have been asking ever since August the 25th, I believe.

BREAM: Today's question centering on guns.

SEN. DIANNE FEINSTEIN (D-), CALIFORNIA: I never thought this would happen in our country that someone would bring a semiautomatic assault weapon into a school and just mow down children and staff. And so I've been very interested in your thinking on assault weapons.

BREAM: Abortion.

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: I mean, you just can't -- what are you -- what are you doing for lunch, let's overrule Roe v. Wade, it doesn't work that way, right?

BREAM: And on this evolution regarding whether a sitting President should be subjected to criminal and civil investigations while in office. As a member of Ken Starr's team, he advocated for aggressively questioning then- President Bill Clinton and helped to write a Starr report, outlining the grounds for Clinton's eventual impeachment. Years later he authored a law review article questioning the wisdom of subjecting sitting Presidents to invasive investigations.

While noting Congress holds the ultimate remedy, impeachment.

BRETT KAVANAUGH, SUPREME COURT NOMINEE: What changed was September 11th. That's what's changed. President Bush said this will not happen again and he was a single-minded focus every morning for the next seven years for President Bush was still September 12th, 2001.

BREAM: And at Kavanaugh's time in the Bush White House post 9/11 that sparked numerous questions about whether he was involved in crafting warrantless surveillance programs or enhanced interrogation policies and the legal memos used to justify them.

KAVANAUGH: I was not read into that program, not involved in crafting that program nor crafting the legal justifications for that program.

BREAM: Also today spectators got a glimpse of human side of the nominee who -- when asked how he'd like to be remembered as good dad and judge and then paused.

FEINSTEIN: Good husband.

GRAHAM: I think he's getting there.

KAVANAUGH: Good husband.

GARAHAM: Thanks, Dianne, you helped him a lot.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BREAM: Late in the day, Democratic Senator Dick Blumenthal asked the nominee to commit to recusing himself from any civil or criminal case involving the President that would come before him as justice, he repeatedly declined. Lou?

DOBBS: Shannon, thank you. Shannon Bream. Joining us tonight, Republican Congressman Andy Biggs, he is a member of House Judiciary Committee and the Freedom Caucus. Congressman, good to have you with us. Your impression of the conduct of the Dems on the Senate Judiciary Committee over two days.

REP. ANDY BIGGS (R), ARIZONA: Well, I'm kind of embarrassed for them. I mean, I watched for instance Mr. Durbin -- Senator Durbin and Senator Leahy asked questions and quite frankly they're fishing and I will just tell you, Judge Kavanaugh made them look so inept and unable to even understand that they were -- they were looking inept. So, not only is he far more brilliant, far more articulate.

He's got an encyclopedic memory, he's gracious about embarrassing the Democrats in such a way that they don't even realize how small they are compared to him.

BREAM: I think you have expressed exactly -- when I listened to Kamala Harris and Dick Durbin, frankly some of the Republicans as they try to stay up with him, it was a very -- it was very revealing both as to their capacity and the -- and the nominee's extraordinary talent and intellect as you say. Let's turn to where we go from here. Are we are going to see this nominee be approved and be ready for the fall term on the Supreme Court?

BIGGS: My understanding is that they're going wrap this thing up sometime mid to late September and that he will be confirmed and that he'll be sitting there for the October session and that's my hope. I mean, look, this guy is really talented. He is really a brilliant jurist, great -- just a great man.

DOBBS: Yes. You know, this nominee Kavanaugh and sitting on the court, the President's other nominee, Neil Gorsuch, I mean, these are -- these are world-class intellects and legal minds, it's wonderful to behold. Let's turn now to social media. We had a couple of folks show up to talk about their bias and what they were doing with Russian meddling and frankly smart people, they seem to have a lot of trouble with the language.

BIGGS: Well, you know, they really do, Lou. And here's the part I love about it. I mean, speaking of anonymous things that have gone on today, yes, they're saying, well, this happened for liberals too, well, can you name some? Well, no, we can't. We're not going the name some. The reason is because I can name people, I can name organizations right now who I know were -- had this prejudice against and they were censored but -- and I'll name them.

But they won't even do that because I don't think it's there, I think their algorithms were designed to specifically root out the conservatives and what -- to blame it on the people who are hitting on the conservative sites was outrageous in my opinion.

DOBBS: Are we headed toward regulations of the social media and big tech organizations? Because they are threatening to be arbiters of what is tasteful, what is acceptable, what is appropriate, what is the standard for discourse?

BIGGS: Well, I think the root of where we need to go is to determine who owns the content. I mean, first of all, they don't know whether a lot of people are boxed or real people that they're trying to weed out, but beyond that, we -- let's find out who really owns the content because if they own the content, then they're liable for suppression, they're liable for slander, they're liable for any of this.

DOBBS: Well, there are two ways that the signals get set around the worldwide web, one is by wire and the other is by air and the fact is, the government of the United States, the people of the United States have claimed them both. Congressman, as always, great to see you, we appreciate it. Andy Biggs.

BIGGS: Thanks, Lou.

DOBBS: Thank you. Up next, social media giants Twitter and Facebook answering questions about why they silenced conservative voices and even admit to dropping -- well, just failing to detect or act on Russian election meddling.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHERYL SANDBERG, CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER, FACEBOOK: Russia used social media as part of and I quote, "a comprehensive and multifaceted campaign to set discord, undermine Democratic institutions and interfere in U.S. election and those of our allies. We were too slow to spot this and to slow to act.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Mnemonic, don't you think? We take it up after the break with folks who are -- their minds are alive, Diamond and Silk, electric and coming up next. Stay with us. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Well, I can't wait to talk with Diamond and Silk about what is going on in Washington and social media. As Congress is -- well, they're - - in some cases hinting that they may want to regulate social media, big tech, Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey among those on Capitol Hill today talking about his company silencing of conservative voices and his defense leaving just a little to be desired.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DORSEY: We don't consider political viewpoints, perspectives or party affiliation in any of our policies or enforcement decisions.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The allegation that we made, the Republicans, is that you're discriminatory against us, against the republicans.

DORSEY: We agree that the result was not impartial and that is why we corrected and we fixed it.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: So do you agree that there were more Republicans than Democrats?

DORSEY: I didn't say that but I do -- I do --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Well, you can't have it both ways, sir.

DORSEY: We don't always have the best methods to determine who is a Republican, who is a Democrat or we have to --

(CROSSTALK)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Well, usually it's known because we run as Republicans or Democrats, that's not hard to identify.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Dorsey not impressing us certainly on this broadcast, investors weren't too impressed either. Twitter stock falling more than six percent today. Dorsey is going to have to up his game, we will see how that goes from here. Joining us now, social media super stars, President Trump supporters, Diamond and Silk. Great to have you here on a day in which social media was, well, in the court of public opinion on Capitol Hill.

What did you make of Dorsey and his comments and Sandberg from Facebook, her comments of the day, Diamond?

LYNNETTE HARDAWAY, SOCIAL MEDIA PERSONALITY: Well, you know what, here is the deal, you have the same people that go up to the Capitol Hill and they just chat and they just talk, and they get nothing done, they say nothing that will take and apiece the American people especially conservatives that's being centered on their platform.

ROCHELLE RICHARDSON, SOCIAL MEDIA PERSONALITY: That's right.

HARDAWAY: To think that you can influence, you can influence what we talk about or what we socialize about on social media, that is dictatorship and that is tyranny and that has got to stop.

DOBBS: Well, you're exactly right because it is -- this is Soviet stuff, talking about whether Facebook or Twitter, who -- whatever platform it might be, they decide what can be said, they decide what will be an acceptable expression, they become the arbiters of taste and judgment and appropriate speech, go to hell.

HARDAWAY: Absolutely.

RICHARDSON: You got that right. And then they want to sit and talk about that Russia as the one that's influencing the election. It's these platforms, Twitter, Facebook, YouTube, Google, the social media platforms that is -- are the ones that's influencing this election because you know what, I don't speak Russia, I speak English, I've never been to Russia and I don't -- you know, if anybody said anything to me in Russia, I wouldn't know what they're talking about.

DOBBS: Right.

RICHARDSON: It's the social media platforms that's influencing this election by silencing and censoring conservative lawyers.

HARDAWAY: That's right.

DOBBS: Well, Sandberg acknowledging that the -- they were slow to respond at Facebook. It turns out that the first collusion may have been on Facebook with the Russians and they didn't react, they didn't bring in authorities from the, you know, from our intelligence agencies, Twitter, you know, I couldn't understand what Dorsey was even trying to say, he wanted to be the guy who decides whether or not conservatives have a voice.

But then he said he couldn't tell which is which, it got really kind of ambiguous for him, could you straighten him out on that, Diamond?

HARDAWAY: Well, first of all, he's not the arbitrator of truth.

RICHARDSON: That's right.

HARDAWAY: So to think that he can influence but he's not the school, he's not the school of speech, this is free speech that we're talking about being stifled.

RICHARDSON: That's right.

HARDAWAY: This is conservative free speech. And what they did, the pretext of all of these here is algorithms that they put in place to silence conservative voices. If you say the word Trump, you're silenced, if you say anything patriotic, stand for the flag or anything about god, you are silenced. If you are a conservative, you are being silenced on the social media of platforms because they want to act like they are the arbitrators of truth and they nothing but liars and really thieves. Yes, lairs and thieves.

RICHARDSON: That's right.

DOBBS: Well, Diamond and Silk, it's great to have you here. We thank you, I want to apologize for swearing, my wife is going to chastise me strongly after the broadcast I'm sure. Forgive me and we're delight to see you, all the best. Thanks so much.

HARDAWAY: Thank you so much.

RICHARDSON: Thank you for having us.

DOBBS: Be sure to check out Diamond and Silk's chitchat tour, their next stop is October 7 in Marietta, Georgia. Nike launching its controversial ad campaign featuring NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick. Tomorrow Nike will run its ad on the NFL'S season opener but the social justice warriors and newly self-proclaimed at Nike have a -- well, something of a spotty history when it comes to social justice and the American worker.

Nike, it turns out -- are you ready? Has 127 footwear factories located in 15 countries. Well, Vietnam, China and Indonesia manufacturing 94 percent of Nike footwear. Also, Nike has 363 apparel factories. They're in 37 countries and make 52 percent of Nike apparel in China, Vietnam and Thailand. That's right, not Ohio, not Oklahoma, not in Oregon, by the way, let's don't forget.

Nike is the same company that put a New York screen printing company out of business and shipped T-shirt printing and production from a factory in New York to Honduras just three years ago. That resulted in the loss of 85 American jobs, 1700 laid off last year, so much for social warrior footwear company or wearing at least at the margin about American workers. Odd, but they're claiming and what they're actually doing. Nike raising our consciousness.

Be sure to vote on our poll tonight, the question is do you think "The New York Times" anonymous op-ed is merely further evidence that President Trump is right when he calls the national left-wing media fake news? Cast your vote on Twitter @LouDobbs, follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs, like me on Facebook, follow me on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight. Up next, a new call for President Trump to declassify FISA documents.

And further expose the systematic bias and efforts to subvert the presidency of Donald J. Trump at the Justice Department and the FBI. I'll be joined by Gregg Jarrett right after this quick break. Stay with us. We're coming right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Key members of the House of Representatives will be calling on President Trump tomorrow to declassify the Carter-Page FISA application and notes from disgraced Justice Department official Bruce Ohr, Freedom Caucus Chair, Mark Meadows along with Congressman Jim Jordan, Matt Gaetz, and Lee Zeldin say, they will make that formal request of the President tomorrow.

Joining us now to assess all of this and much more, Gregg Jarrett, a Fox Legal Analyst and author of "The New York Times" best-selling book, The Russia Hoax. Great to have you here.

GREGG JARRETT, FOX BUSINESS LEGAL ANALYST: Good to be here, Lou.

DOBBS: Let's start with Meadows and Jordan and Gaetz going over to -- and Zeldin going over to the White House to talk to the President.

JARRETT: Right.

DOBBS: This, you know, for a example, Tom Fitton has been calling for this, we've all been calling this for ages. The President, why in your judgment has he not already done it?

JARRETT: He's being misled by the intelligence community. I suspect it's not just the FBI director but the DNI, Dan Coats. As well as others, probably Rod Rosenstein, why? Because first of all for the intelligence community, they think when they order a pizza it's national security and ought to be classified. There's this mentality that everything they do is so important. It's got to be classified and that's nonsense.

Every time something is declassified we find out it shouldn't have been classified to begin with and second of all, I think the FBI, Christopher Wray is covering up the wrongdoing of his own bureau and these documents will reveal a level of corruption that will stun most Americans and it'll be largely exculpatory of the President.

DOBBS: People forget, some of the Congressmen have seen --

JARRETT: Oh sure. So they know what's in it.

DOBBS: They know, they can make independent judgment and they can --

JARRETT: And they have.

DOBBS: Yes, they have and have made it very clear that it's B.S. what is being peddled whether it's by the intelligence community whether it's being his attorneys and his, you know, his political folks. There is just no way in the world this President needs to let this go any further, it has got to stop, it's got to stop now.

JARRETT: The American public deserves to see what's in these documents. They deserve to see the impropriety and I believe illegality perpetrated by the FBI and the Department of Justice to target Trump to try to influence the election and undo the results.

DOBBS: I think in your rack it is called so stipulated. I mean, this has been demonstrated evidence throughout. We know what we're dealing with, a corrupt leadership that's still entrenched in the FBI. They have taken out the top but they haven't taken out all of the -- of the corruption. It's a toxic agency.

JARRETT: It is.

DOBBS: And only perhaps a competitive with that agency is the Department of Justice itself.

JARRETT: Absolutely.

DOBBS: And that's got to be fixed. This is a president who is --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: -- should be on Jeff Sessions who has been abysmal and derelict in his duties as attorney general. And now he has an opportunity to make things happen irrespective of the willful resistance within his administration.

JARRETT: Everybody in Washington and America at large knows that Jeff Sessions is finished. Jeff Sessions may not get it but he will right after the elections. But the perfect example is he's allowed Bruce Ohr of all people to still be employed in the Department of Justice and we learned 10 days ago when when he implicated all of the people at the FBI who were involved in elicit scheme including believe it or not, Andrew Weissmann, the lead prosecutor in the Special Counsel Bob Mueller's investigation.

Which is now tainted and corrupted the integrity and credibility of that investigation.

DOBBS: Which had none to begin with.

JARRETT: Exactly.

DOBBS: So stipulated.

JARRETT: So stipulated, counselor.

DOBBS: All right. Thanks so much for being with us, Gregg. Thank you.

JARRETT: My pleasure.

DOBBS: Gregg Jarrett. And the book is "The Russia Hoax." Buy a couple more copies, would you?

JARRETT: Buy 10.

DOBBS: I mean, this guy has got to think at some point about his children.

(CROSSTALK)

JARRETT: Getting old.

DOBBS: Well, his retirement as well, we'll throw that in. Up next, the resistance making its way inside the White House, that's what an op-ed in "The New York Times" by an anonymous, anonymous author would have -- "The New York Times" would have you believe. Oh. Wow. That's pretty bad. We'll take up that so called senior official in the Trump administration.

Yale professor Paul Bracken joins us. We're going to take up a lot of issues within as we continue here tonight. Stay with us, we'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: The left wing "New York Times", I know that's partly Redundant elevating its ideological fervour and that's kind -- a very kind way to call it what it is. Publishing not just an anonymous quote but an entire anonymous op-ed from an alleged member of the administration who bashed the president, and that's not allegedly that's definitively. If this is just the latest escalation in the fourth estates assault on President Trump. And no one -- no one should take seriously the claim that the author of this anonymous op-ed is truly a senior administration official. President Trump addressed the op-ed during the White House event this very afternoon.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Yes, the sheriffs can imagine this, we have somebody in what I call the failing "New York Times", that's talking about he's part of the resistance within the Trump administration. This is what we have to deal with. And you know, the dishonest media because you people deal with it as well as I do but it's really a disgrace. I will say this, nobody has done what this administration has done in terms of getting things passed and getting things through.

When you tell me about some anonymous source within the administration probably who's failing and probably here for all the wrong reasons now. And "The New York Times" is failing. If I weren't here, I believe "The New York Times" probably wouldn't even exist. And someday, (INAUDIBLE) and someday when I'm not president, which hopefully will be in about 6-1/2 years from now.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

TRUMP: "The "New York Times"" and CNN and all of these phony media outlets will be out of business folks, they'll be out of business. Because there'll be nothing to write and there'll be nothing of interest.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Well the president is absolutely correct when he suggests that the copy won't be quite as elevated or exciting when he finally leaves the presidency.

Joining us tonight Paul Bracken, he's a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, he's professor of political science and business at Yale University. A great American, it's great to have you here.

PAUL BRACKEN, PROFESSOR OF POLITICAL SCIENCE AND BUSINESS, YALE UNIVERSITY: Good to be here.

DOBBS: Let's start with the President and this anonymous quote by some worm that allegedly is in the -- who is allegedly a part of the administration. Your thoughts about where the "New York Times" is.

BRACKEN: My thoughts are this, first of all, the "The New York Times" would have vetted this very carefully about who it is. So, I don't have any doubts about that. My feeling is yet another example of partisan politics run riot, it's the way I would put it. DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: It's happening everywhere and it's not good for the democracy. I don't think it's good for U.S. security overseas. It can tempt people to think the wrong things about that we have a weak government.

And I was shocked that the individual in question would not resign and put it out there under his own name.

DOBBS: Yes, I wasn't surprised. Anyone who would betray the man they work for this president of the United States, is a delusional ego maniacal, self-aggrandizing jackass. I don't see any other way to call it. I would think that that person would I hope stand out clearly amongst the top officials of the administration.

BRACKEN: See, this is not like that you work for a big business.

DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: And you don't agree with the CEO or something like that.

DOBBS: Right, it's national security.

BRACKEN: This is -- this is you work for the United States government and you worked with the Constitution. And if you really don't agree with it, you should be in there and you have special obligations that are far larger than people who work at most kinds of organizations.

DOBBS: Yes, this would also be a call. This would also be a call to the deep state, whether it's in the FBI. We've seen the corruption that is rampant in its leadership, the Department of Justice. All of those people should be walking out the door because they are appalling in their disloyalty. The ignorance of their conduct, the political corruption that they have with which they've stained those that Department and that agency.

BRACKEN: Well, the way I would put it is that we have made it much easier to impeach the next president whoever it is after this one.

DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: We are lowering the bar here and we are going to suffer for the sins of both parties but especially in recent times. It is not good for the strength of this country and a lot of other things going well on the economic front and the foreign policy front. And but on the political front, they're not.

DOBBS: This president is his successes to this point in time in his administration are unprecedented in the modern era, am I correct?

BRACKEN: You are correct. The one that gets me is the charge that he's drawn to authoritarian governments like Russia and China, which belies the fact that he's -- he has launched the largest nuclear build up, it's going to add thousands of hydrogen bombs aimed at Russia and China. I do not see this is coddling the Russians.

DOBBS: Nor do I.

BRACKEN: And the Russians do not see it that way. I was just in Russia as you know.

DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: And talking to a lot of officials there, they are absolutely stunned at the thought that we believe that they could hack the U.S. election and make a difference. They can't do anything right in their own country and they're stunned to think that we think they won our election, they tilted it.

DOBBS: Folks have a -- should have a pretty good insight into Russian government just by the historical facts that is in 1991 with the collapse of the Soviet Union and Marxist Leninist. I mean, the country is struggling now not just because of the sanctions, although there are a tremendous burden. But because the country has yet to embrace markets and --

BRACKEN: Right.

DOBBS: -- to achieve its potential.

BRACKEN: Their backward technologically. There is no Silicon Valley in Russia, they've tried to sort it several times.

DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: The Ruble is collapsing. The biggest thing I -- you know what I and people talk about in Russia, it wasn't hacking the election, it wasn't Donald Trump, they are extremely upset because the Ruble is going down so much.

DOBBS: Sure.

BRACKEN: That they can't take their vacations on the Riviera this year.

DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: That's what the Russians I spoke to were really upset about.

DOBBS: They're upset about that, they're also obviously very interested in reclaiming at least full power in the Atlantic. The United States now creating a countervailing Atlantic Fleet to the force that already the Russians have put into the Atlantic.

BRACKEN: Well, we've done a lot in the last few years. We've got some very interesting military technologies. And there are now NATO battalions in the three Baltic countries.

DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: They would have to kill NATO troops if they come in and invade. And that gets them into a ball game that they do not want to get into.

DOBBS: And the reason they're there in large measure is because Estonia that the Baltic -- the Baltic are without question historically they've had enough of Russian invasion.

BRACKEN: That's an understatement. Yes, they do not like the Russians.

DOBBS: Well, we like you and we're delighted that you have taken time to join us. Hope you'll be back with us soon.

BRACKEN: Thank you.

DOBBS: Thanks professor. Appreciate it, Paul Bracken.

In other headlines tonight, more than 500 passengers aboard an aircraft from Dubai had to be screened by health officials. They were quarantined at JFK Airport at least ten of them taken to the hospital. Flu-like symptoms were the description. The CDC is investigating what caused them to fall ill.

And new worries for the Gulf States as hurricane Florence strengthened in the Atlantic to a category four storm. This after tropical storm Gordon approved deadly last night, killing a child in Florida.

And president Trump describing the trade talks that have resumed as of today. He describes those talks as intense but says the United States doesn't have much to lose. And he doesn't much mind if Canada decides not to be a part of the trading bloc that already now includes the United States and Mexico as a result of their bilateral trade agreement.

Extremist groups like black lives matter backing the new sponsorship deal between Nike and Colin Kaepernick. Taking an unpatriotic and disgraceful stance against police officers across the country who risk their lives every single day. Since 2014, there have been 212 police officers killed across the country in the line of duty. And in some of our largest cities such as Chicago. Black lives don't seem to matter of the 382 people killed in Chicago this year. 308 of them African-American. This is the same city that is now begging for a larger more engaged police force. But continues to vote for failed leaders like the outgoing Mayor Rahm Emanuel who after promising to hire a thousand new police officers in 2016 has brought in just about 600.

Instead of looking to a failed NFL quarterback who sacrificed a few million dollars to take a knee during our national anthem. Perhaps Nike should have looked at the men and the women who sacrificed everything on our streets all across the country. Think about it Nike, just do it.

Up next, Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh vows his independence on the bench as his hearing churns through another day of venomous demonstrations from liberal loonies of all sorts senatorial and just plain protesters.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: (INAUDIBLE)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: (INAUDIBLE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: First, I didn't understand a word of that. We'll have more on it after the break. I'll be talking with author David Kaplan here next. Stay with us. You don't want to miss it.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: President Trump slamming the anonymous source to "The New York Times" if such a source exists. The president tweeted this just minutes ago. This is the president's tweet, does the so-called senior administration official really exist or is it just the failing New York Times with another phony source? If the gutless anonymous person does indeed exist, the times must, for national security purposes turn him/her over to the government at once. There you are. The radical Dimms continue to foolishly and savagely oppose.

Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh firing off outlandish questions today in addition to orchestrating more demonstrations by protesters in the hearing room as the president's choice for the High Court had to put up with it all.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Be required to respond to a subpoena.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Do you still believe a president can fire it will a prosecutor who is criminally investigating him?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I would like your commitment that you will recuse yourself if there is an issue involving his criminal or civil liability.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Since you became a legal adult, have you ever made unwanted requests for sexual favors or committed any verbal or physical harassment or assault of a sexual nature?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Good Lord. Well, joining us tonight, I am pleased to tell you is David Kaplan he's former legal affairs editor for Newsweek. Author of the new book The Most Dangerous Branch: Inside The Supreme Courts Assault On The Constitution. David, great to have you with us.

DAVID KAPLAN, AUTHOR, THE MOST DANGEROUS BRANCH: Good to be with you.

DOBBS: I want to first show folks a picture of the two of us in Fortune Magazine.

KAPLAN: No.

DOBBS: Yes, we got that please. One, two, three. I did it on three. I timely (INAUDIBLE) here.

KAPLAN: Fake armrest.

DOBBS: That was fake?

KAPLAN: It looks real.

DOBBS: I was working like heck to just stay a parody there.

KAPLAN: Yes.

DOBBS: Well, what do you think of the sweater David?

KAPLAN: It's a lot nicer than my sport jacket.

DOBBS: Well, that's us. What year was that? 90?

KAPLAN: I think that was like 2010.

DOBBS: That's what I said 2010.

KAPLAN: Once upon a time.

DOBBS: That's it. It seemed like 93 to me but there it is.

KAPLAN: Who won that match?

DOBBS: Well, you and I both can claim it.

KAPLAN: Yes, I think I probably let you win.

DOBBS: Yes, thank you -- thank you. I'm sure that I deferred. But I do - -

KAPLAN: We do that to most of the people we wrote about it Newsweek and fortune.

DOBBS: You got it -- you got it.

DOBBS: It's great to have you here. Congratulations on the book.

KAPLAN: Thank you.

DOBBS: It couldn't be more timely and judge Brett Kavanaugh. I'm watching these hearings and I honestly have never seen anything like it. This is --

KAPLAN: Sure you have, last year.

DOBBS: No.

KAPLAN: Except for the protest, fair enough.

DOBBS: This is -- this is venomous. 76 people arrested in two days. This is -- the Dimms are putting on a show that it looks to me like it's politically suicidal.

KAPLAN: I don't know how it's going to play politically but it's predictable. It's illogical -- it's a logical extension of where hearings have been going for 20 years. And if Hillary Clinton was president and she had put up a nominee, I think you'd see Republicans misbehaving. Neither side has a claim to good behavior.

But in the first instance -- in the first instance, the problem with these hearings isn't senators, it's not even presidents. It's the Supreme Court. They're complicit in this because by issuing rulings on so many controversial issues they raise the stakes of being on the Supreme Court. And you're seeing that play out now.

DOBBS: Now you argue in your book that the Supreme Court has overreached and it's -- that's an understatement in its rulings. Which is to you the most egregious, which is the most profound in its impact.

KAPLAN: Well, you know, choosing among bad rulings is like deciding which of your children you love most. But I think if I had to choose Bush v. Gore in 2000.

DOBBS: Right.

KAPLAN: Was the most egregious but I criticized Roe v. Wade. I criticized the campaign-finance ruling as citizens united the gun control ruling and I criticized the gay marriage decision. There's plenty of criticism on left and right. So, there's plenty in the book for both sides to like or to hate.

DOBBS: So, we have to turn to The Most Dangerous Branch. We recommend the book to you highly by David Kaplan. You're fair and balanced and you're an equal-opportunity -- well, sceptic of both in a detractor of both. The Gore v. --

KAPLAN: Bush v. Gore.

DOBBS: Bush v. -- I knew I had it backwards, Bush v. Gore.

KAPLAN: They're easily confused.

DOBBS: Yes, they are. They were actually -- they were a little more alike than we would like to think I think. The idea that you don't like that hurts me, because I thought we were friends and that you would automatically signed with Bush. You obviously chosen a separate path.

KAPLAN: But we're -- it's between friends. But the mistake I fear Lou that you're making is confusing criticism of the court's decision to intervene at all --

DOBBS: Right.

KAPLAN: -- with the outcome.

DOBBS: Right.

KAPLAN: To the extent for example that I criticize Roe v. Wade, it's not because I disagree with the outcome. Politically, I'm liberal. I believe in very liberalized abortion laws. I don't think though that victory should be achieved in court, I think it should be achieved in Congress or in state legislatures similarly, whether you wanted Bush or Gore to win. The victory was best one in Congress because that's what the Constitution provided for in the case of a disputed presidential election. Instead, both sides went to court to achieve victory and that's what I criticize.

DOBBS: As you have studied this and written about it over two years -- written about it over two years to produce the book. Is there a point at which you think that the court can be either be righted or right itself?

KAPLAN: I'm not optimistic, what you're seeing playing out in the Kavanaugh hearings is an indication of how bad things have become. But I think the best hope lies not with presidents or senators but with the court itself. The courts going to have to learn to restrain itself.

DOBBS: David Kaplan, again, congratulations.

KAPLAN: Thank you.

DOBBS: Great to see you.

KAPLAN: Good to see you. We're not going to arm-wrestle here. All right, next time.

DOBBS: I got to have a couple of more days in the weight room.

Up next President Trump mulling whether or not he should declassified documents at the heart of the Mueller never-ending witch-hunt. We'll have the latest when we come back.

This is the book, "The Most Dangerous, Dangerous Branch," David Kaplan. We recommend it to you. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T6R-DF51-DY0W-4478-00000-00Twitter And Facebook Executives Testify Before Congress; Protests Disrupt Second Day Of Kavanaugh Confirmation Hearings; 'New York Times' Runs Anonymous Op-Ed from Trump Administration Official; Radical Dems Pepper Kavanaugh with Outlandish Questions2018-09-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:58ZLexisNexisTwitter And Facebook Executives Testify Before Congress; Protests Disrupt Second Day Of Kavanaugh Confirmation Hearings; 'New York Times' Runs Anonymous Op-Ed from Trump Administration Official; Radical Dems Pepper Kavanaugh with Outlandish QuestionsLanhamFULL TEXT

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Let's see if they do. By the way, Vince, congratulations again. Great job. Here's Lou.

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. Our top stories, day two of the Kavanaugh Supreme Court confirmation hearings, the radical Dems still trying to disrupt and delay those hearings in spite of the outrageous ignorant conduct of the committee Dems and leftist protestors, President Trump's high court nominee handling their ignorance with grace and constraint.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I've watched his remarks, I've watched his performance, I've watched his statements and honestly they've been totally brilliant. I think that the other side is grasping at straws and really the other side should embrace it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Embrace it. We'll take up the latest on those hearings tonight, Congressman Andy Biggs among our guest. Also Fox Legal Analyst, Gregg Jarrett. Also, social media executives embarrassingly unprepared on Capitol Hill exposing themselves as unable, unwilling to address election meddling issues and acknowledge their political bias.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PATRICK DORSEY, FOUNDER AND CEO, TWITTER: We found ourselves unprepared and ill-equipped for the immensity of the problems that we've acknowledged.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: As for Google, didn't even show up, leaving lawmakers staring at empty an chair and perhaps -- just perhaps dreaming of ways to bring Google to heel. We take that up tonight with conservative social media starts, Diamond and Silk. And "The New York Times" taking fake news to the next level from anonymous sources to entire anonymous op-eds with anonymous quotes thrown in.

The President isn't too impressed by either "The Times" or the gutless wonder anonymous op-ed author.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: If the failing "New York Times" has an anonymous editorial, can you believe it? Anonymous, meaning gutless, a gutless editorial, we're doing a great job, the poll numbers are through the roof, our poll numbers are great and guess what, nobody is going to come close to beating me in 2020.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: We'll have more on the cowardly self-proclaimed senior official little worm who chose to betray and to attack the President that is if you believe the Times' claim about any of this. Our top story, the confirmation hearing for Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh still underway despite Dems spewing ignorance and vitriol all over the hearing room above it all Kavanaugh who makes his little effusion inquisitors from the left look ever smaller.

Fox News Chief Legal Correspondent and Anchor of "FOX NEWS @ NIGHT" Shannon Bream joining us from Capitol Hill with the latest.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

TRUMP: I've watched his performance, I've watched his statements and honestly they've been totally brilliant.

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS HOST: President Trump praising his second Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh as the judge continues to run a gauntlet marked by protestors. And Senators still jousting over document production.

SEN. PATRICK LEAHY (D), VERMONT: I would ask the chairman if he might look at some of these remarked committee confidential.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Let me answer that for you, if you're interested in it, you could have been asking ever since August the 25th, I believe.

BREAM: Today's question centering on guns.

SEN. DIANNE FEINSTEIN (D-), CALIFORNIA: I never thought this would happen in our country that someone would bring a semiautomatic assault weapon into a school and just mow down children and staff. And so I've been very interested in your thinking on assault weapons.

BREAM: Abortion.

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: I mean, you just can't -- what are you -- what are you doing for lunch, let's overrule Roe v. Wade, it doesn't work that way, right?

BREAM: And on this evolution regarding whether a sitting President should be subjected to criminal and civil investigations while in office. As a member of Ken Starr's team, he advocated for aggressively questioning then- President Bill Clinton and helped to write a Starr report, outlining the grounds for Clinton's eventual impeachment. Years later he authored a law review article questioning the wisdom of subjecting sitting Presidents to invasive investigations.

While noting Congress holds the ultimate remedy, impeachment.

BRETT KAVANAUGH, SUPREME COURT NOMINEE: What changed was September 11th. That's what's changed. President Bush said this will not happen again and he was a single-minded focus every morning for the next seven years for President Bush was still September 12th, 2001.

BREAM: And at Kavanaugh's time in the Bush White House post 9/11 that sparked numerous questions about whether he was involved in crafting warrantless surveillance programs or enhanced interrogation policies and the legal memos used to justify them.

KAVANAUGH: I was not read into that program, not involved in crafting that program nor crafting the legal justifications for that program.

BREAM: Also today spectators got a glimpse of human side of the nominee who -- when asked how he'd like to be remembered as good dad and judge and then paused.

FEINSTEIN: Good husband.

GRAHAM: I think he's getting there.

KAVANAUGH: Good husband.

GARAHAM: Thanks, Dianne, you helped him a lot.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BREAM: Late in the day, Democratic Senator Dick Blumenthal asked the nominee to commit to recusing himself from any civil or criminal case involving the President that would come before him as justice, he repeatedly declined. Lou?

DOBBS: Shannon, thank you. Shannon Bream. Joining us tonight, Republican Congressman Andy Biggs, he is a member of House Judiciary Committee and the Freedom Caucus. Congressman, good to have you with us. Your impression of the conduct of the Dems on the Senate Judiciary Committee over two days.

REP. ANDY BIGGS (R), ARIZONA: Well, I'm kind of embarrassed for them. I mean, I watched for instance Mr. Durbin -- Senator Durbin and Senator Leahy asked questions and quite frankly they're fishing and I will just tell you, Judge Kavanaugh made them look so inept and unable to even understand that they were -- they were looking inept. So, not only is he far more brilliant, far more articulate.

He's got an encyclopedic memory, he's gracious about embarrassing the Democrats in such a way that they don't even realize how small they are compared to him.

BREAM: I think you have expressed exactly -- when I listened to Kamala Harris and Dick Durbin, frankly some of the Republicans as they try to stay up with him, it was a very -- it was very revealing both as to their capacity and the -- and the nominee's extraordinary talent and intellect as you say. Let's turn to where we go from here. Are we are going to see this nominee be approved and be ready for the fall term on the Supreme Court?

BIGGS: My understanding is that they're going wrap this thing up sometime mid to late September and that he will be confirmed and that he'll be sitting there for the October session and that's my hope. I mean, look, this guy is really talented. He is really a brilliant jurist, great -- just a great man.

DOBBS: Yes. You know, this nominee Kavanaugh and sitting on the court, the President's other nominee, Neil Gorsuch, I mean, these are -- these are world-class intellects and legal minds, it's wonderful to behold. Let's turn now to social media. We had a couple of folks show up to talk about their bias and what they were doing with Russian meddling and frankly smart people, they seem to have a lot of trouble with the language.

BIGGS: Well, you know, they really do, Lou. And here's the part I love about it. I mean, speaking of anonymous things that have gone on today, yes, they're saying, well, this happened for liberals too, well, can you name some? Well, no, we can't. We're not going the name some. The reason is because I can name people, I can name organizations right now who I know were -- had this prejudice against and they were censored but -- and I'll name them.

But they won't even do that because I don't think it's there, I think their algorithms were designed to specifically root out the conservatives and what -- to blame it on the people who are hitting on the conservative sites was outrageous in my opinion.

DOBBS: Are we headed toward regulations of the social media and big tech organizations? Because they are threatening to be arbiters of what is tasteful, what is acceptable, what is appropriate, what is the standard for discourse?

BIGGS: Well, I think the root of where we need to go is to determine who owns the content. I mean, first of all, they don't know whether a lot of people are boxed or real people that they're trying to weed out, but beyond that, we -- let's find out who really owns the content because if they own the content, then they're liable for suppression, they're liable for slander, they're liable for any of this.

DOBBS: Well, there are two ways that the signals get set around the worldwide web, one is by wire and the other is by air and the fact is, the government of the United States, the people of the United States have claimed them both. Congressman, as always, great to see you, we appreciate it. Andy Biggs.

BIGGS: Thanks, Lou.

DOBBS: Thank you. Up next, social media giants Twitter and Facebook answering questions about why they silenced conservative voices and even admit to dropping -- well, just failing to detect or act on Russian election meddling.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHERYL SANDBERG, CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER, FACEBOOK: Russia used social media as part of and I quote, "a comprehensive and multifaceted campaign to set discord, undermine Democratic institutions and interfere in U.S. election and those of our allies. We were too slow to spot this and to slow to act.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Mnemonic, don't you think? We take it up after the break with folks who are -- their minds are alive, Diamond and Silk, electric and coming up next. Stay with us. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Well, I can't wait to talk with Diamond and Silk about what is going on in Washington and social media. As Congress is -- well, they're - - in some cases hinting that they may want to regulate social media, big tech, Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey among those on Capitol Hill today talking about his company silencing of conservative voices and his defense leaving just a little to be desired.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DORSEY: We don't consider political viewpoints, perspectives or party affiliation in any of our policies or enforcement decisions.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The allegation that we made, the Republicans, is that you're discriminatory against us, against the republicans.

DORSEY: We agree that the result was not impartial and that is why we corrected and we fixed it.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: So do you agree that there were more Republicans than Democrats?

DORSEY: I didn't say that but I do -- I do --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Well, you can't have it both ways, sir.

DORSEY: We don't always have the best methods to determine who is a Republican, who is a Democrat or we have to --

(CROSSTALK)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Well, usually it's known because we run as Republicans or Democrats, that's not hard to identify.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Dorsey not impressing us certainly on this broadcast, investors weren't too impressed either. Twitter stock falling more than six percent today. Dorsey is going to have to up his game, we will see how that goes from here. Joining us now, social media super stars, President Trump supporters, Diamond and Silk. Great to have you here on a day in which social media was, well, in the court of public opinion on Capitol Hill.

What did you make of Dorsey and his comments and Sandberg from Facebook, her comments of the day, Diamond?

LYNNETTE HARDAWAY, SOCIAL MEDIA PERSONALITY: Well, you know what, here is the deal, you have the same people that go up to the Capitol Hill and they just chat and they just talk, and they get nothing done, they say nothing that will take and apiece the American people especially conservatives that's being centered on their platform.

ROCHELLE RICHARDSON, SOCIAL MEDIA PERSONALITY: That's right.

HARDAWAY: To think that you can influence, you can influence what we talk about or what we socialize about on social media, that is dictatorship and that is tyranny and that has got to stop.

DOBBS: Well, you're exactly right because it is -- this is Soviet stuff, talking about whether Facebook or Twitter, who -- whatever platform it might be, they decide what can be said, they decide what will be an acceptable expression, they become the arbiters of taste and judgment and appropriate speech, go to hell.

HARDAWAY: Absolutely.

RICHARDSON: You got that right. And then they want to sit and talk about that Russia as the one that's influencing the election. It's these platforms, Twitter, Facebook, YouTube, Google, the social media platforms that is -- are the ones that's influencing this election because you know what, I don't speak Russia, I speak English, I've never been to Russia and I don't -- you know, if anybody said anything to me in Russia, I wouldn't know what they're talking about.

DOBBS: Right.

RICHARDSON: It's the social media platforms that's influencing this election by silencing and censoring conservative lawyers.

HARDAWAY: That's right.

DOBBS: Well, Sandberg acknowledging that the -- they were slow to respond at Facebook. It turns out that the first collusion may have been on Facebook with the Russians and they didn't react, they didn't bring in authorities from the, you know, from our intelligence agencies, Twitter, you know, I couldn't understand what Dorsey was even trying to say, he wanted to be the guy who decides whether or not conservatives have a voice.

But then he said he couldn't tell which is which, it got really kind of ambiguous for him, could you straighten him out on that, Diamond?

HARDAWAY: Well, first of all, he's not the arbitrator of truth.

RICHARDSON: That's right.

HARDAWAY: So to think that he can influence but he's not the school, he's not the school of speech, this is free speech that we're talking about being stifled.

RICHARDSON: That's right.

HARDAWAY: This is conservative free speech. And what they did, the pretext of all of these here is algorithms that they put in place to silence conservative voices. If you say the word Trump, you're silenced, if you say anything patriotic, stand for the flag or anything about god, you are silenced. If you are a conservative, you are being silenced on the social media of platforms because they want to act like they are the arbitrators of truth and they nothing but liars and really thieves. Yes, lairs and thieves.

RICHARDSON: That's right.

DOBBS: Well, Diamond and Silk, it's great to have you here. We thank you, I want to apologize for swearing, my wife is going to chastise me strongly after the broadcast I'm sure. Forgive me and we're delight to see you, all the best. Thanks so much.

HARDAWAY: Thank you so much.

RICHARDSON: Thank you for having us.

DOBBS: Be sure to check out Diamond and Silk's chitchat tour, their next stop is October 7 in Marietta, Georgia. Nike launching its controversial ad campaign featuring NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick. Tomorrow Nike will run its ad on the NFL'S season opener but the social justice warriors and newly self-proclaimed at Nike have a -- well, something of a spotty history when it comes to social justice and the American worker.

Nike, it turns out -- are you ready? Has 127 footwear factories located in 15 countries. Well, Vietnam, China and Indonesia manufacturing 94 percent of Nike footwear. Also, Nike has 363 apparel factories. They're in 37 countries and make 52 percent of Nike apparel in China, Vietnam and Thailand. That's right, not Ohio, not Oklahoma, not in Oregon, by the way, let's don't forget.

Nike is the same company that put a New York screen printing company out of business and shipped T-shirt printing and production from a factory in New York to Honduras just three years ago. That resulted in the loss of 85 American jobs, 1700 laid off last year, so much for social warrior footwear company or wearing at least at the margin about American workers. Odd, but they're claiming and what they're actually doing. Nike raising our consciousness.

Be sure to vote on our poll tonight, the question is do you think "The New York Times" anonymous op-ed is merely further evidence that President Trump is right when he calls the national left-wing media fake news? Cast your vote on Twitter @LouDobbs, follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs, like me on Facebook, follow me on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight. Up next, a new call for President Trump to declassify FISA documents.

And further expose the systematic bias and efforts to subvert the presidency of Donald J. Trump at the Justice Department and the FBI. I'll be joined by Gregg Jarrett right after this quick break. Stay with us. We're coming right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Key members of the House of Representatives will be calling on President Trump tomorrow to declassify the Carter-Page FISA application and notes from disgraced Justice Department official Bruce Ohr, Freedom Caucus Chair, Mark Meadows along with Congressman Jim Jordan, Matt Gaetz, and Lee Zeldin say, they will make that formal request of the President tomorrow.

Joining us now to assess all of this and much more, Gregg Jarrett, a Fox Legal Analyst and author of "The New York Times" best-selling book, The Russia Hoax. Great to have you here.

GREGG JARRETT, FOX BUSINESS LEGAL ANALYST: Good to be here, Lou.

DOBBS: Let's start with Meadows and Jordan and Gaetz going over to -- and Zeldin going over to the White House to talk to the President.

JARRETT: Right.

DOBBS: This, you know, for a example, Tom Fitton has been calling for this, we've all been calling this for ages. The President, why in your judgment has he not already done it?

JARRETT: He's being misled by the intelligence community. I suspect it's not just the FBI director but the DNI, Dan Coats. As well as others, probably Rod Rosenstein, why? Because first of all for the intelligence community, they think when they order a pizza it's national security and ought to be classified. There's this mentality that everything they do is so important. It's got to be classified and that's nonsense.

Every time something is declassified we find out it shouldn't have been classified to begin with and second of all, I think the FBI, Christopher Wray is covering up the wrongdoing of his own bureau and these documents will reveal a level of corruption that will stun most Americans and it'll be largely exculpatory of the President.

DOBBS: People forget, some of the Congressmen have seen --

JARRETT: Oh sure. So they know what's in it.

DOBBS: They know, they can make independent judgment and they can --

JARRETT: And they have.

DOBBS: Yes, they have and have made it very clear that it's B.S. what is being peddled whether it's by the intelligence community whether it's being his attorneys and his, you know, his political folks. There is just no way in the world this President needs to let this go any further, it has got to stop, it's got to stop now.

JARRETT: The American public deserves to see what's in these documents. They deserve to see the impropriety and I believe illegality perpetrated by the FBI and the Department of Justice to target Trump to try to influence the election and undo the results.

DOBBS: I think in your rack it is called so stipulated. I mean, this has been demonstrated evidence throughout. We know what we're dealing with, a corrupt leadership that's still entrenched in the FBI. They have taken out the top but they haven't taken out all of the -- of the corruption. It's a toxic agency.

JARRETT: It is.

DOBBS: And only perhaps a competitive with that agency is the Department of Justice itself.

JARRETT: Absolutely.

DOBBS: And that's got to be fixed. This is a president who is --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: -- should be on Jeff Sessions who has been abysmal and derelict in his duties as attorney general. And now he has an opportunity to make things happen irrespective of the willful resistance within his administration.

JARRETT: Everybody in Washington and America at large knows that Jeff Sessions is finished. Jeff Sessions may not get it but he will right after the elections. But the perfect example is he's allowed Bruce Ohr of all people to still be employed in the Department of Justice and we learned 10 days ago when when he implicated all of the people at the FBI who were involved in elicit scheme including believe it or not, Andrew Weissmann, the lead prosecutor in the Special Counsel Bob Mueller's investigation.

Which is now tainted and corrupted the integrity and credibility of that investigation.

DOBBS: Which had none to begin with.

JARRETT: Exactly.

DOBBS: So stipulated.

JARRETT: So stipulated, counselor.

DOBBS: All right. Thanks so much for being with us, Gregg. Thank you.

JARRETT: My pleasure.

DOBBS: Gregg Jarrett. And the book is "The Russia Hoax." Buy a couple more copies, would you?

JARRETT: Buy 10.

DOBBS: I mean, this guy has got to think at some point about his children.

(CROSSTALK)

JARRETT: Getting old.

DOBBS: Well, his retirement as well, we'll throw that in. Up next, the resistance making its way inside the White House, that's what an op-ed in "The New York Times" by an anonymous, anonymous author would have -- "The New York Times" would have you believe. Oh. Wow. That's pretty bad. We'll take up that so called senior official in the Trump administration.

Yale professor Paul Bracken joins us. We're going to take up a lot of issues within as we continue here tonight. Stay with us, we'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: The left wing "New York Times", I know that's partly Redundant elevating its ideological fervour and that's kind -- a very kind way to call it what it is. Publishing not just an anonymous quote but an entire anonymous op-ed from an alleged member of the administration who bashed the president, and that's not allegedly that's definitively. If this is just the latest escalation in the fourth estates assault on President Trump. And no one -- no one should take seriously the claim that the author of this anonymous op-ed is truly a senior administration official. President Trump addressed the op-ed during the White House event this very afternoon.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Yes, the sheriffs can imagine this, we have somebody in what I call the failing "New York Times", that's talking about he's part of the resistance within the Trump administration. This is what we have to deal with. And you know, the dishonest media because you people deal with it as well as I do but it's really a disgrace. I will say this, nobody has done what this administration has done in terms of getting things passed and getting things through.

When you tell me about some anonymous source within the administration probably who's failing and probably here for all the wrong reasons now. And "The New York Times" is failing. If I weren't here, I believe "The New York Times" probably wouldn't even exist. And someday, (INAUDIBLE) and someday when I'm not president, which hopefully will be in about 6-1/2 years from now.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

TRUMP: "The "New York Times"" and CNN and all of these phony media outlets will be out of business folks, they'll be out of business. Because there'll be nothing to write and there'll be nothing of interest.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Well the president is absolutely correct when he suggests that the copy won't be quite as elevated or exciting when he finally leaves the presidency.

Joining us tonight Paul Bracken, he's a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, he's professor of political science and business at Yale University. A great American, it's great to have you here.

PAUL BRACKEN, PROFESSOR OF POLITICAL SCIENCE AND BUSINESS, YALE UNIVERSITY: Good to be here.

DOBBS: Let's start with the President and this anonymous quote by some worm that allegedly is in the -- who is allegedly a part of the administration. Your thoughts about where the "New York Times" is.

BRACKEN: My thoughts are this, first of all, the "The New York Times" would have vetted this very carefully about who it is. So, I don't have any doubts about that. My feeling is yet another example of partisan politics run riot, it's the way I would put it. DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: It's happening everywhere and it's not good for the democracy. I don't think it's good for U.S. security overseas. It can tempt people to think the wrong things about that we have a weak government.

And I was shocked that the individual in question would not resign and put it out there under his own name.

DOBBS: Yes, I wasn't surprised. Anyone who would betray the man they work for this president of the United States, is a delusional ego maniacal, self-aggrandizing jackass. I don't see any other way to call it. I would think that that person would I hope stand out clearly amongst the top officials of the administration.

BRACKEN: See, this is not like that you work for a big business.

DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: And you don't agree with the CEO or something like that.

DOBBS: Right, it's national security.

BRACKEN: This is -- this is you work for the United States government and you worked with the Constitution. And if you really don't agree with it, you should be in there and you have special obligations that are far larger than people who work at most kinds of organizations.

DOBBS: Yes, this would also be a call. This would also be a call to the deep state, whether it's in the FBI. We've seen the corruption that is rampant in its leadership, the Department of Justice. All of those people should be walking out the door because they are appalling in their disloyalty. The ignorance of their conduct, the political corruption that they have with which they've stained those that Department and that agency.

BRACKEN: Well, the way I would put it is that we have made it much easier to impeach the next president whoever it is after this one.

DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: We are lowering the bar here and we are going to suffer for the sins of both parties but especially in recent times. It is not good for the strength of this country and a lot of other things going well on the economic front and the foreign policy front. And but on the political front, they're not.

DOBBS: This president is his successes to this point in time in his administration are unprecedented in the modern era, am I correct?

BRACKEN: You are correct. The one that gets me is the charge that he's drawn to authoritarian governments like Russia and China, which belies the fact that he's -- he has launched the largest nuclear build up, it's going to add thousands of hydrogen bombs aimed at Russia and China. I do not see this is coddling the Russians.

DOBBS: Nor do I.

BRACKEN: And the Russians do not see it that way. I was just in Russia as you know.

DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: And talking to a lot of officials there, they are absolutely stunned at the thought that we believe that they could hack the U.S. election and make a difference. They can't do anything right in their own country and they're stunned to think that we think they won our election, they tilted it.

DOBBS: Folks have a -- should have a pretty good insight into Russian government just by the historical facts that is in 1991 with the collapse of the Soviet Union and Marxist Leninist. I mean, the country is struggling now not just because of the sanctions, although there are a tremendous burden. But because the country has yet to embrace markets and --

BRACKEN: Right.

DOBBS: -- to achieve its potential.

BRACKEN: Their backward technologically. There is no Silicon Valley in Russia, they've tried to sort it several times.

DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: The Ruble is collapsing. The biggest thing I -- you know what I and people talk about in Russia, it wasn't hacking the election, it wasn't Donald Trump, they are extremely upset because the Ruble is going down so much.

DOBBS: Sure.

BRACKEN: That they can't take their vacations on the Riviera this year.

DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: That's what the Russians I spoke to were really upset about.

DOBBS: They're upset about that, they're also obviously very interested in reclaiming at least full power in the Atlantic. The United States now creating a countervailing Atlantic Fleet to the force that already the Russians have put into the Atlantic.

BRACKEN: Well, we've done a lot in the last few years. We've got some very interesting military technologies. And there are now NATO battalions in the three Baltic countries.

DOBBS: Right.

BRACKEN: They would have to kill NATO troops if they come in and invade. And that gets them into a ball game that they do not want to get into.

DOBBS: And the reason they're there in large measure is because Estonia that the Baltic -- the Baltic are without question historically they've had enough of Russian invasion.

BRACKEN: That's an understatement. Yes, they do not like the Russians.

DOBBS: Well, we like you and we're delighted that you have taken time to join us. Hope you'll be back with us soon.

BRACKEN: Thank you.

DOBBS: Thanks professor. Appreciate it, Paul Bracken.

In other headlines tonight, more than 500 passengers aboard an aircraft from Dubai had to be screened by health officials. They were quarantined at JFK Airport at least ten of them taken to the hospital. Flu-like symptoms were the description. The CDC is investigating what caused them to fall ill.

And new worries for the Gulf States as hurricane Florence strengthened in the Atlantic to a category four storm. This after tropical storm Gordon approved deadly last night, killing a child in Florida.

And president Trump describing the trade talks that have resumed as of today. He describes those talks as intense but says the United States doesn't have much to lose. And he doesn't much mind if Canada decides not to be a part of the trading bloc that already now includes the United States and Mexico as a result of their bilateral trade agreement.

Extremist groups like black lives matter backing the new sponsorship deal between Nike and Colin Kaepernick. Taking an unpatriotic and disgraceful stance against police officers across the country who risk their lives every single day. Since 2014, there have been 212 police officers killed across the country in the line of duty. And in some of our largest cities such as Chicago. Black lives don't seem to matter of the 382 people killed in Chicago this year. 308 of them African-American. This is the same city that is now begging for a larger more engaged police force. But continues to vote for failed leaders like the outgoing Mayor Rahm Emanuel who after promising to hire a thousand new police officers in 2016 has brought in just about 600.

Instead of looking to a failed NFL quarterback who sacrificed a few million dollars to take a knee during our national anthem. Perhaps Nike should have looked at the men and the women who sacrificed everything on our streets all across the country. Think about it Nike, just do it.

Up next, Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh vows his independence on the bench as his hearing churns through another day of venomous demonstrations from liberal loonies of all sorts senatorial and just plain protesters.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: (INAUDIBLE)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: (INAUDIBLE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: First, I didn't understand a word of that. We'll have more on it after the break. I'll be talking with author David Kaplan here next. Stay with us. You don't want to miss it.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: President Trump slamming the anonymous source to "The New York Times" if such a source exists. The president tweeted this just minutes ago. This is the president's tweet, does the so-called senior administration official really exist or is it just the failing New York Times with another phony source? If the gutless anonymous person does indeed exist, the times must, for national security purposes turn him/her over to the government at once. There you are. The radical Dimms continue to foolishly and savagely oppose.

Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh firing off outlandish questions today in addition to orchestrating more demonstrations by protesters in the hearing room as the president's choice for the High Court had to put up with it all.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Be required to respond to a subpoena.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Do you still believe a president can fire it will a prosecutor who is criminally investigating him?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I would like your commitment that you will recuse yourself if there is an issue involving his criminal or civil liability.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Since you became a legal adult, have you ever made unwanted requests for sexual favors or committed any verbal or physical harassment or assault of a sexual nature?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Good Lord. Well, joining us tonight, I am pleased to tell you is David Kaplan he's former legal affairs editor for Newsweek. Author of the new book The Most Dangerous Branch: Inside The Supreme Courts Assault On The Constitution. David, great to have you with us.

DAVID KAPLAN, AUTHOR, THE MOST DANGEROUS BRANCH: Good to be with you.

DOBBS: I want to first show folks a picture of the two of us in Fortune Magazine.

KAPLAN: No.

DOBBS: Yes, we got that please. One, two, three. I did it on three. I timely (INAUDIBLE) here.

KAPLAN: Fake armrest.

DOBBS: That was fake?

KAPLAN: It looks real.

DOBBS: I was working like heck to just stay a parody there.

KAPLAN: Yes.

DOBBS: Well, what do you think of the sweater David?

KAPLAN: It's a lot nicer than my sport jacket.

DOBBS: Well, that's us. What year was that? 90?

KAPLAN: I think that was like 2010.

DOBBS: That's what I said 2010.

KAPLAN: Once upon a time.

DOBBS: That's it. It seemed like 93 to me but there it is.

KAPLAN: Who won that match?

DOBBS: Well, you and I both can claim it.

KAPLAN: Yes, I think I probably let you win.

DOBBS: Yes, thank you -- thank you. I'm sure that I deferred. But I do - -

KAPLAN: We do that to most of the people we wrote about it Newsweek and fortune.

DOBBS: You got it -- you got it.

DOBBS: It's great to have you here. Congratulations on the book.

KAPLAN: Thank you.

DOBBS: It couldn't be more timely and judge Brett Kavanaugh. I'm watching these hearings and I honestly have never seen anything like it. This is --

KAPLAN: Sure you have, last year.

DOBBS: No.

KAPLAN: Except for the protest, fair enough.

DOBBS: This is -- this is venomous. 76 people arrested in two days. This is -- the Dimms are putting on a show that it looks to me like it's politically suicidal.

KAPLAN: I don't know how it's going to play politically but it's predictable. It's illogical -- it's a logical extension of where hearings have been going for 20 years. And if Hillary Clinton was president and she had put up a nominee, I think you'd see Republicans misbehaving. Neither side has a claim to good behavior.

But in the first instance -- in the first instance, the problem with these hearings isn't senators, it's not even presidents. It's the Supreme Court. They're complicit in this because by issuing rulings on so many controversial issues they raise the stakes of being on the Supreme Court. And you're seeing that play out now.

DOBBS: Now you argue in your book that the Supreme Court has overreached and it's -- that's an understatement in its rulings. Which is to you the most egregious, which is the most profound in its impact.

KAPLAN: Well, you know, choosing among bad rulings is like deciding which of your children you love most. But I think if I had to choose Bush v. Gore in 2000.

DOBBS: Right.

KAPLAN: Was the most egregious but I criticized Roe v. Wade. I criticized the campaign-finance ruling as citizens united the gun control ruling and I criticized the gay marriage decision. There's plenty of criticism on left and right. So, there's plenty in the book for both sides to like or to hate.

DOBBS: So, we have to turn to The Most Dangerous Branch. We recommend the book to you highly by David Kaplan. You're fair and balanced and you're an equal-opportunity -- well, sceptic of both in a detractor of both. The Gore v. --

KAPLAN: Bush v. Gore.

DOBBS: Bush v. -- I knew I had it backwards, Bush v. Gore.

KAPLAN: They're easily confused.

DOBBS: Yes, they are. They were actually -- they were a little more alike than we would like to think I think. The idea that you don't like that hurts me, because I thought we were friends and that you would automatically signed with Bush. You obviously chosen a separate path.

KAPLAN: But we're -- it's between friends. But the mistake I fear Lou that you're making is confusing criticism of the court's decision to intervene at all --

DOBBS: Right.

KAPLAN: -- with the outcome.

DOBBS: Right.

KAPLAN: To the extent for example that I criticize Roe v. Wade, it's not because I disagree with the outcome. Politically, I'm liberal. I believe in very liberalized abortion laws. I don't think though that victory should be achieved in court, I think it should be achieved in Congress or in state legislatures similarly, whether you wanted Bush or Gore to win. The victory was best one in Congress because that's what the Constitution provided for in the case of a disputed presidential election. Instead, both sides went to court to achieve victory and that's what I criticize.

DOBBS: As you have studied this and written about it over two years -- written about it over two years to produce the book. Is there a point at which you think that the court can be either be righted or right itself?

KAPLAN: I'm not optimistic, what you're seeing playing out in the Kavanaugh hearings is an indication of how bad things have become. But I think the best hope lies not with presidents or senators but with the court itself. The courts going to have to learn to restrain itself.

DOBBS: David Kaplan, again, congratulations.

KAPLAN: Thank you.

DOBBS: Great to see you.

KAPLAN: Good to see you. We're not going to arm-wrestle here. All right, next time.

DOBBS: I got to have a couple of more days in the weight room.

Up next President Trump mulling whether or not he should declassified documents at the heart of the Mueller never-ending witch-hunt. We'll have the latest when we come back.

This is the book, "The Most Dangerous, Dangerous Branch," David Kaplan. We recommend it to you. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END
